Pre-emption occurs when Congress, in enacting a federal statute, expresses a clear intent to pre-empt state law, Jones v. Rath Packing Co., 430 U.S. 519 (1977), when there is outright or actual conflict between federal and state law, e.g., Free v. Bland, 369 U.S. 663 (1962), where compliance with both federal and state law is in effect physically impossible, Florida Lime & Avocado Growers, Inc. v. Paul, 373 U.S. 132 (1963), where there is implicit in federal law a barrier to state regulation, Shaw v. Delta Air Lines, Inc., 463 U.S. 85 (1983), where Congress has legislated comprehensively, thus occupying an entire field of regulation and leaving no room for the States to supplement federal law, Rice v. Santa Fe Elevator Corp., 331 U.S. 218 (1947), or where the state law stands as [Page 369] an obstacle to the accomplishment and execution of the full objectives of Congress. Hines v. Davidowitz, 312 U.S. 52 (1941). Pre-emption may result not only from action taken by Congress itself; a federal agency acting within the scope of its congressionally delegated authority may pre-empt state regulation. Fidelity Federal Savings & Loan Assn. v. De la Cuesta, 458 U.S. 141 (1982); Capital Cities Cable, Inc. v. Crisp, 467 U.S. 691 (1984).”
 
 What these two scholars fail to understand (or refuse to concede???) is that their contrived and overly restrictive “militia service only right” is already within the exclusive control of Congress under Article I Section 8:
 
 “To provide for organizing, arming, and disciplining, the militia, and for governing such part of them as may be employed in the service of the United States, reserving to the states respectively, the appointment of the officers, and the authority of training the militia according to the discipline prescribed by Congress.”
 
 Congress has the exclusive power to choose how large the state militia will be, who will be considered a member and who will not, how they will be armed, and how they will be disciplined. And if the right to keep and bear arms is limited only to militia service, as these scholars suggest, then it is not a right at all—it merely becomes a privilege incidental to militia service which Congress has the total power to grant or withhold. This point was addressed in Heller:
 
 “Besides ignoring the historical reality that the Second Amendment was not intended to lay down a “novel principl[e]” but rather codified a right “inherited from our English ancestors,” Robertson v. Baldwin, 165 U.S. 275, 281 (1897), petitioners' interpretation does not even achieve the narrower purpose that prompted codification of the right. If, as they believe, the Second Amendment right is no more than the right to keep and use weapons as a member of an organized militia, see Brief for Petititioners 8 — if, that is, the organized militia is the sole institutional [Slip Op. 27] beneficiary of the Second Amendment's guarantee — it does not assure the existence of a “citizens' militia” as a safeguard against tyranny. For Congress retains plenary authority to organize the militia, which must include the authority to say who will belong to the organized force.17 That is why the first Militia Act's requirement that only whites enroll caused States to amend their militia laws to exclude free blacks. See Siegel, The Federal Government's Power to Enact Color-Conscious Laws, 92 Nw. U. L. Rev. 477, 521-525 (1998). Thus, if petitioners are correct, the Second Amendment protects citizens' right to use a gun in an organization from which Congress has plenary authority to exclude them. It guarantees a select militia of the sort the Stuart kings found useful, but not the people's militia that was the concern of the founding generation.” District Of Columbia v. Heller, 554 U.S. ___ 07290, 26-27 (2008)
 
 Additionally, many anti-federalists complained that if Congress were given the exclusive power to arm the militia then Congress could effectively disarm the state militias simply by refusing to exercise its authority to arm them. 
 
 The federalist response was essentially “so what?” The people were already armed (and, as Miller noted, the practice of the time was for the militias to be made up of men “bearing arms supplied by themselves”—arms they had a right to own and possess unattached to any militia duty). This individual right to keep and bear arms exists apart from and beyond the Congressional power to arm the militias. See, for example:
 
 “The power of the sword, say the minority of Pennsylvania, is in the hands of Congress. My friends and countrymen, it is not so, for the powers of the sword are in the hands of the yeomanry of America from sixteen to sixty. The militia of these free commonwealths, entitled and accustomed to their arms, when compared with any possible army, must be tremendous and irresistible. Who are the militia? Are they not ourselves? Is it feared, then, that we shall turn our arms each man against his own bosom? Congress shall have no power to disarm the militia. Their swords and every other terrible implement of the soldier, are the birth-right of an American ....[T]he unlimited power of the sword is not in the hands of either the federal or the state governments, but where I trust in God it will ever remain, in the hands of the People.” Tench Coxe, Pennsylvania Gazette, Feb. 20, 1788. 
 
 “Before a standing army can rule, the people must be disarmed; as they are in almost every kingdom of Europe. The supreme power in America cannot enforce unjust laws by the sword; because the whole body of the people are armed, and constitute a force superior to any bands of regular troops that can be, on any pretense, raised in the United States. A military force, at the command of Congress, can execute no laws, but such as the people perceive to be just and constitutional; for they will possess the power, and jealousy will instantly inspire the inclination, to resist the execution of a law which appears to them unjust and oppressive.” Noah Webster, "An Examination into the Leading Principles of the Federal Constitution." (1787) in Pamphlets on the Constitution of the United States (P. Ford, 1888).
 
 The view clearly was that Congress cannot exercise a monopoly over arms because the people have a concurrent individual right to have arms. If Congress formed an army of tyranny and both refused to arm the militias and forbade the states from providing arms to the militias, then the people in an emergency could provide their own arms.
 
 Every court which has looked upon the issue has held that the Bill of Rights acts as a check upon the power of the federal government. Yet these scholars suggest the 2nd. Amendment is nothing more than an unnecessary statement that you have a right to keep and bear arms if Congress allows you to have them. 
 
 This is a fraudulent argument with no basis in history or law. I too would like to see the footnotes cited in this writing to see where they support this assertion. The scholars say “To the Supreme Court” which implies they believe the Presser Court viewed the right that way. Presser most certainly did not make this assumption. If there is another case they refer to in the footnote I would like to read it. 
 
 They do cite, however, Illinois Senator Lyman Trumball as a supporter of this “militia service only right” view. Senator Trumball is widely known for having condemned the actions of the Mississippi state militia, which he accused of roaming throughout that state to habitually "hang some freedmen or search negro houses for arms.” Congressional Globe, 39th. Congress, 1st. Session, part 1, Senate Report Number 30, p. 813 (February 13, 1866) [Speech of Senator Lyman Trumball (Republican-Illinois). Trumball was also known to support the expressed congressional purpose of the 14th. Amendment—which was to incorporate the first 8 amendments in the BoR against the states. 
 
 Yet the two scholars argue that Trumball believed the RKBA only protected the black man’s right to join up with and carry arms amongst the same racist militia members who sought to disarm and lynch him? 
 
 I too share Rick’s disbelief here. I would like to see the sources in the footnote. For Trumball to be associated with this argument is unknown to me this side of the looking glass.
